channel.title: Opinion about a new PC
channel.description:
Well I'm in need for a new PC, and I don't got the free time atm to build one my self. So I was searching for what looked decent and found this:
OS: Windows Vista Home Premium 32 or 64 CPU: Intel Core 2 Quad Q9450 GFX: NVIDIA GeForce 9600GT Memory: 1000 GB HDD RAM: 2x 2GB
Specs: Intel® Core 2 Quad Q9450 Speed: 2,66 GHz Front Side Bus (FSB): 1333 MHz L2 Cache: 12 MB
NVIDIA® GeForce® 9600GT Memorytype: GDDR3 Memory: 512 MB Memory frequency: 900 MHz active cooled by fan 2x DVI-I, S-Video out
4 GB intern Memory Memory Modules: 2x 2 GB 2 memory banks installed, 2 banks free Memory Type: DDR2 PC 6400 Memory Speed: 800 MHz
1000 GB HDD Speed: 7200 RPM Interface: S-ATA 2 Buffersize: 16 MB Cache
Is this worth the €800,00? I know that it comes preinstalled with Vista 32 bits version, I'll be formatting the hell out of it and install the 64 bits version to make use of the full 4 GB's of RAM (they supply both the 32 and 64 bits version).

item.title: Opinion about a new PC
item.dc:creator: @Monkey_wacko Monkey wacko
item.description:
@Monkey_wacko wrote:

Well i would say that’s the price range for those specs. Although it seems like you might get a better graphics card for that price. Also Look into the Core i7 Processors i happen to have one myself. They are amazing!

Read full topic

item.title: Opinion about a new PC
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

You guys should stop comparing newegg prices with shops he can actually order from, and keep in mind he want’s it prebuilt.

Newegg is about 30% cheaper than anything around my area.

people who can order from newegg and can build their own computer manually, can create goodness for such a small price.

Read full topic

item.title: Opinion about a new PC
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:15, topic:262769”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=347005.msg2672761#msg2672761 date=1234898120]
Waffendennis is Dutch, so UK prices won’t matter either.

But do you really have no time to assemble one yourself? It only takes 1 hour max if you have the right parts.
[/quote]

Also, you need the right tools. Took me almost half an hour to get the old heatsink/cpu off my computer. As soon as I used a knife as a lever, it came off. Putting the new one on took about 15 secs.[/quote]

But when you have brand new parts, you don’t have to disassemble anything. All you need then is a screwdriver.

Read full topic

item.title: Opinion about a new PC
item.dc:creator: @Waffendennis Waffendennis
item.description:
@Waffendennis wrote:

[quote=“Bebe, post:13, topic:262769”][quote author=ThAt0n36Uy link=topic=347005.msg2672967#msg2672967 date=1234903635]

You should just build one waffendennis, we just built my brother a similar computer for $400.

I don’t got the free time atm to build one my self.

Waffendennis is Dutch, so UK prices won’t matter either.

But do you really have no time to assemble one yourself? It only takes 1 hour max if you have the right parts.

[/quote]
He already said he cba’d to build it himself so it doesn’t matter…[/quote]

Well that, and if I manufacter it my self it’s actualy around the same price! The prices of pc hardware aren’t what they used to be anymore. I tried ordering it from newegg, but they wont send it to the Netherlands.

Newegg list:

CPU: Intel Core 2 Quad Q8200 2.33GHz LGA 775 95W Quad-Core Processor Model BX80580Q8200 - Retail $169,99
Motherboard: Open Box: ASUS P5Q3 DELUXE/WIFI-AP CH1-11 LGA 775 Intel P45 ATX Intel Motherboard $151,50
RAM: mushkin HP 4GB (2 x 2GB) 240-Pin DDR3 SDRAM DDR3 1600 (PC3 12800) Dual Channel Kit Desktop Memory - Retail $99,99
HDD: SAMSUNG Spinpoint F1 HD103UJ 1TB 7200 RPM SATA 3.0Gb/s Hard Drive - OEM $94,99
GFX Card: XFX PVT98GYDLU GeForce 9800 GT 512MB 256-bit GDDR3 PCI Express 2.0 x16 HDCP Ready SLI Supported Video Card - Retail $129,99
SFX: Creative Sound Blaster X-Fi Xtreme Audio 7.1 Channels PCI Express Interface Sound Card - OEM $49,99
DVD Burner: ASUS 22X DVD Burner with LightScribe Black IDE Model DRW-22B1L - Retail $26,99
DVD/Blue Ray player: Sony Optiarc Black 5X Blu-Ray DVD ROM & 12X DVD Burner SATA Model BC-5100S - OEM $99,99
Casing: SIGMA La Vie LBYWBP Leather Black SECC Steel ATX Mid Tower Computer Case 500W Power Supply - Retail $84,99

I think that’s it!
Total: $908,13
But then I have the following items that are better than the €800,00 pc:
CPU
GFX
SFX
RAM
HDD
Motherboard

Read full topic

item.title: Opinion about a new PC
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

No it isnt. You could get the gateway fx desktop with core i7 and hd4850 for the same price.

There is also a dell studio xps thats cheaper than the gateway. Only problem with the dell is the shitty psu in it that cannot support the graphics card

http://www.bestbuy.com/site/olspage.jsp?skuId=9180423&type=product&id=1218046802234

http://www.bestbuy.com/site/olspage.jsp?skuId=9081325&st=gateway+fx&lp=2&type=product&cp=1&id=1218017465909

that’s US tho, dunno about UK

Read full topic

item.title: Opinion about a new PC
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

  1. It’s hard to say, but id say it’s close as shops do charge quite a bit of money putting a pc together (and i assume this pc comes with a case if they are setting it up) ?

  2. You’ll end up getting an active 3.5gb ram on that setup, so going 64bit for an extra 512mb ram is not the best since you’ll lose compatibility on 64bit.

But if #1 is correct, id say its only just worth it. Try bump it up to a 9800gt and keep the same price.

Read full topic
